requirement: A Data Fiduciary shall ensure the completeness, accuracy, and consistency of personal data.
requirement_description: Data Fiduciaries must ensure that personal data is accurate, complete, and consistent, particularly when making decisions or disclosing data to other parties.

controls.control: Implement data validation and verification processes to ensure that personal data is accurate, complete, and consistent. This includes using data quality checks, data profiling, and data cleansing techniques to identify and correct errors or inconsistencies.

Standardize and normalize personal data to ensure consistency across different systems and processes. This includes using standardized data formats, data dictionaries, and data mapping techniques to ensure that data is accurately and consistently represented.

Establish a data quality monitoring and reporting process to track and report on data accuracy, completeness, and consistency. This includes using data quality metrics, dashboards, and reports to identify trends and areas for improvement.

Assign data stewards and owners to ensure that personal data is properly managed and maintained. This includes defining roles and responsibilities, data governance policies, and data access controls to ensure that data is accurate, complete, and consistent.

Establish a data retention and archiving policy to ensure that personal data is properly stored and disposed of. This includes defining data retention periods, data archiving procedures, and data disposal protocols to ensure that data is not retained for longer than necessary.

Establish a data backup and recovery process to ensure that personal data is properly backed up and recoverable in the event of a disaster or data loss. This includes defining data backup frequencies, data recovery procedures, and data storage protocols to ensure that data is recoverable.

requirement: A Data Fiduciary shall implement technical and organisational measures to ensure compliance.
requirement_description: Data Fiduciaries must implement measures to ensure compliance with the Act and its rules.

controls.control: Implement access control measures to restrict access to sensitive data and systems, including multi-factor authentication, role-based access control, and least privilege access. This will ensure that only authorized personnel can access sensitive data and systems.

controls.control_title: Conduct Regular Security Audits and Risk Assessments
controls.control: Conduct regular security audits and risk assessments to identify vulnerabilities and weaknesses in the system. This will help to identify areas for improvement and ensure that the system is secure and compliant with regulatory requirements.

Implement data encryption to protect sensitive data both in transit and at rest. This will ensure that even if data is intercepted or accessed by unauthorized personnel, it will be unreadable and unusable.

controls.control_title: Develop and Implement Incident Response Plan
controls.control: Develop and implement an incident response plan to ensure that the organization is prepared to respond to security incidents and data breaches. This will help to minimize the impact of an incident and ensure that the organization is compliant with regulatory requirements.

Provide security awareness training to all personnel to educate them on security best practices and the importance of data protection. This will help to ensure that personnel are aware of their responsibilities and are taking steps to protect sensitive data.

controls.control_title: Maintain Accurate Records of Security Measures
controls.control: Maintain accurate records of security measures, including access logs, security audits, and incident response plans. This will help to demonstrate compliance with regulatory requirements and provide evidence of security measures in the event of an audit or investigation.

requirement: A Data Fiduciary shall protect personal data with reasonable security safeguards.
requirement_description: Data Fiduciaries must take reasonable measures to protect personal data from breaches.

controls.control: All personal data shall be encrypted both in transit and at rest using industry-standard encryption algorithms (e.g., AES-256) and protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2).

controls.control_title: Use Secure Protocols for Data Transmission
controls.control: All data transmission shall be conducted over secure protocols (e.g., HTTPS, SFTP) to prevent interception and eavesdropping.

All systems and applications handling personal data shall implement robust access controls and authentication mechanisms (e.g., multi-factor authentication, role-based access control) to ensure only authorized personnel can access the data.

controls.control_title: Regularly Update and Patch Systems and Applications
controls.control: All systems and applications handling personal data shall be regularly updated and patched to ensure they have the latest security fixes and vulnerabilities are addressed.

controls.control_title: Conduct Regular Security Audits and Risk Assessments
controls.control: Regular security audits and risk assessments shall be conducted to identify and mitigate potential security risks and vulnerabilities associated with personal data.

controls.control_title: Implement Data Backup and Recovery Procedures
controls.control: Regular backups of personal data shall be conducted and stored securely to ensure business continuity in the event of a data loss or system failure.
All personnel handling personal data shall receive regular data security awareness training to ensure they understand the importance of protecting personal data and the procedures for doing so.

requirement: A Data Fiduciary shall erase personal data upon withdrawal of consent or as required by law.
requirement_description: Data Fiduciaries must erase personal data when consent is withdrawn or as required by law.

controls.control: Develop and implement a data erasure process that can be triggered upon withdrawal of consent or as required by law. This process should ensure that all personal data is completely erased from the system, including backups and archives.

Establish procedures to identify and erase personal data stored in various systems, including databases, files, and other data storage systems. This includes identifying data that is no longer necessary for the purpose for which it was collected.

Provide regular training to personnel on the data erasure process, including the procedures for identifying and erasing personal data, and the importance of data erasure in maintaining compliance with data protection regulations.

Maintain accurate and up-to-date documentation of the data erasure process, including procedures, timelines, and personnel responsible for data erasure. This documentation should be accessible to all personnel involved in the data erasure process.
Establish procedures to verify that personal data has been completely erased from the system, including conducting regular audits and testing the data erasure process to ensure its effectiveness.

Illustrations.
(I) X, an individual, registers herself on an online marketplace operated by Y , an
e-commerce service provider. X gives her consent to Y for the processing of her personal
data for selling her used car. The online marketplace helps conclude the sale. Y shall no
longer retain her personal data.
(II) X, an individual, decides to close her savings account with Y , a bank. Y is required
by law applicable to banks to maintain the record of the identity of its clients for a period of
ten years beyond closing of accounts. Since retention is necessary for compliance with law,
Y shall retain X’s personal data for the said period.

controls.control: Establish and enforce data retention policies that clearly outline the purpose for which personal data is collected, stored, and processed. Regularly monitor and audit data erasure activities to ensure that personal data is being erased in accordance with established policies and procedures. This includes reviewing logs, conducting spot checks, and investigating any discrepancies or non-compliance.

requirement: A Data Fiduciary shall publish its business contact information.
requirement_description: Data Fiduciaries must make their business contact information publicly available.

controls.control_title: Publish Business Contact Information on Website
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall publish its business contact information, including name, address, phone number, and email address, on its official website. This information shall be easily accessible and prominently displayed on the website's homepage or contact page.

The Data Fiduciary shall regularly verify its business contact information to ensure its accuracy and completeness. This includes updating contact information as necessary and removing any outdated or incorrect information.

The Data Fiduciary shall provide multiple channels for individuals to contact the organization, including phone, email, and physical address. This ensures that individuals have multiple options for reaching the organization and submitting inquiries or complaints.

controls.control_title: Include Business Contact Information on Marketing Materials
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall include its business contact information on all marketing materials, including business cards, brochures, and advertisements. This ensures that the organization's contact information is easily accessible to customers and prospects.

controls.control_title: Make Business Contact Information Available in Multiple Languages
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall make its business contact information available in multiple languages to accommodate individuals who may not speak the primary language of the organization. This includes translating contact information on the website and providing multilingual support through phone and email.

requirement: A Data Fiduciary shall establish a grievance redressal mechanism.
requirement_description: Data Fiduciaries must have a process in place to handle and resolve complaints from Data Principals.

controls.control: Develop and implement a comprehensive grievance redressal policy that outlines the procedures for handling and resolving customer complaints, including timelines for response and resolution.

Appoint a Grievance Redressal Officer (GRO) who will be responsible for handling and resolving customer complaints, and ensure that the GRO has the necessary authority and resources to perform their duties effectively.

Clearly communicate the grievance redressal mechanism to customers through various channels, including the website, social media, and customer support channels, to ensure that customers are aware of the process for reporting complaints.

Develop and implement a grievance redressal system that allows customers to report complaints and track the status of their complaints, including a system for logging, tracking, and resolving complaints.

controls.control_title: Monitor and Review the Grievance Redressal Mechanism
controls.control: Regularly monitor and review the grievance redressal mechanism to identify areas for improvement, and make necessary changes to ensure that the mechanism is effective and efficient in resolving customer complaints.

Provide regular training to staff on the grievance redressal mechanism, including the procedures for handling and resolving customer complaints, to ensure that staff are equipped to handle customer complaints effectively.

requirement: A Data Principal shall approach the Data Fiduciary for the performance of the specified purpose.
requirement_description: Data Principals must contact the Data Fiduciary when they want to perform a specified purpose.

controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall establish a notification process for Data Principals to request the performance of a specified purpose. This process shall include a clear and concise description of the purpose, the data to be processed, and the expected outcomes.

The Data Fiduciary shall establish a reasonable timeframe for responding to Data Principal requests for the performance of a specified purpose. This timeframe shall be clearly communicated to Data Principals and shall not exceed [insert timeframe, e.g., 30 days].

The Data Fiduciary shall maintain a record of all Data Principal requests for the performance of a specified purpose. This record shall include the date of the request, the purpose requested, and the outcome of the request.

The Data Fiduciary shall be accountable for ensuring that all Data Principal requests for the performance of a specified purpose are processed in accordance with the applicable laws and regulations. The Data Fiduciary shall maintain records of all requests and outcomes, and shall be able to demonstrate compliance with applicable laws and regulations upon request.

The Data Fiduciary shall obtain explicit consent from the Data Principal prior to processing their data for a specified purpose. This consent shall be obtained through a clear and transparent process, and shall be documented in accordance with applicable laws and regulations.

requirement_description: Data Principals must exercise their rights related to the processing of their personal data.

controls.control: Establish a clear and efficient process for handling DSARs, including a designated contact point and a timeframe for responding to requests. This process should be communicated to data subjects and made easily accessible.

controls.control_title: Right to Erasure (Right to be Forgotten)
controls.control: Implement a process for handling requests to erase personal data, including identifying and deleting or anonymizing data, and notifying third-party processors and recipients of the erasure. This process should be documented and communicated to data subjects.

Obtain explicit and informed consent from data subjects before processing their personal data, and provide clear and transparent information about the purposes and duration of processing. Consent should be documented and easily accessible.

Establish a process for handling requests to correct or update personal data, including verifying the accuracy of the data and updating or correcting it as necessary. This process should be documented and communicated to data subjects.

Notify data subjects of any changes to the purposes or duration of processing their personal data, or of any new processing activities that may affect them. This notification should be clear and transparent, and provided in a timely manner.

requirement_description: Data Fiduciaries must make the time period for approaching and exercising rights publicly available.

controls.control_title: Publish Time Period for Approaching Rights
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall publish the time period for approaching and exercising rights in a clear and conspicuous manner on their website, including the deadline for responding to requests and the timeframe for exercising rights.

controls.control_title: Document Time Period for Approaching Rights
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall maintain a written record of the time period for approaching and exercising rights, including the deadline for responding to requests and the timeframe for exercising rights, and make it available upon request.

controls.control_title: Train Staff on Time Period for Approaching Rights
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall provide training to staff on the time period for approaching and exercising rights, including the deadline for responding to requests and the timeframe for exercising rights, to ensure that they are aware of and can communicate this information to individuals.

controls.control_title: Update Time Period for Approaching Rights
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall update the time period for approaching and exercising rights as necessary, and publish the updated information in a clear and conspicuous manner on their website.

controls.control_title: Communicate Time Period for Approaching Rights to Affected Individuals
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall communicate the time period for approaching and exercising rights to individuals whose data is being processed, including the deadline for responding to requests and the timeframe for exercising rights, in a clear and conspicuous manner.

requirement: A Data Principal must initiate contact with the Data Fiduciary for the performance of a specified purpose.
requirement_description: The Data Principal must take the first step in initiating contact with the Data Fiduciary for the purpose of data processing.

controls.control: The Data Fiduciary must obtain explicit consent from the Data Principal before initiating any contact for the performance of a specified purpose. The Data Fiduciary must also notify the Data Principal of the purpose and any associated risks.

The Data Fiduciary must maintain accurate and up-to-date contact information for the Data Principal, including email, phone number, and physical address. This information must be easily accessible to authorized personnel.

The Data Fiduciary must provide multiple communication channels for the Data Principal to initiate contact, including email, phone, and online forms. This ensures that the Data Principal has a convenient and accessible means of contacting the Data Fiduciary.

The Data Fiduciary must maintain a record of all interactions with the Data Principal, including dates, times, and purposes of contact. This ensures that the Data Fiduciary can demonstrate accountability and transparency in their interactions with the Data Principal.

The Data Fiduciary must provide the Data Principal with the right to opt-out of any contact or communication, including the right to withdraw consent at any time. This ensures that the Data Principal has control over their personal data and can exercise their rights as needed.

requirement_title: Obtain Verifiable Consent for Processing Personal Data of Children or Individuals with Disabilities
article_text:
9. (1) The Data Fiduciary shall, before processing any personal data of a child or a
person with disability who has a lawful guardian obtain verifiable consent of the parent of
such child or the lawful guardian, as the case may be, in such manner as may be prescribed.
Explanation.—For the purpose of this sub-section, the expression “consent  of the
parent” includes the consent of lawful guardian, wherever applicable.
(2) A Data Fiduciary shall not undertake such processing of personal data that is
likely to cause any detrimental effect on the well-being of a child.
(3) A Data Fiduciary shall not undertake tracking or behavioural monitoring of children
or targeted advertising directed at children.
(4) The provisions of sub-sections (1) and (3) shall not be applicable to processing of
personal data of a child by such classes of Data Fiduciaries or for such purposes, and
subject to such conditions, as may be prescribed.
(5) The Central Government may, if satisfied that a Data Fiduciary has ensured that its
processing of personal data of children is done in a manner that is verifiably safe, notify for
such processing by such Data Fiduciary the age above which that Data Fiduciary shall be
exempt from the applicability of all or any of the obligations under sub-sections (1) and (3)
in respect of processing by that Data Fiduciary as the notification may specify.

controls.control_title: Implement Age Verification for Children's Personal Data
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall implement a robust age verification process to ensure that personal data of children is only collected and processed with verifiable consent from a parent or guardian. This process shall include, but not be limited to, verifying the age of the individual and obtaining explicit consent from a parent or guardian before collecting and processing any personal data.

controls.control_title: Develop a Consent Mechanism for Individuals with Disabilities
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall develop a consent mechanism that is accessible and usable by individuals with disabilities. This mechanism shall be designed to accommodate different types of disabilities and shall provide an alternative means of obtaining consent, such as an audio or braille version of the consent form.

controls.control_title: Train Staff on Consent Requirements for Children and Individuals with Disabilities
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall provide regular training to its staff on the requirements for obtaining verifiable consent from children and individuals with disabilities. This training shall include, but not be limited to, the importance of age verification, the development of accessible consent mechanisms, and the handling of sensitive personal data.

The Data Fiduciary shall maintain accurate and up-to-date documentation of its consent processes and procedures for collecting and processing personal data of children and individuals with disabilities. This documentation shall include, but not be limited to, the age verification process, the consent mechanism, and the training provided to staff.

controls.control_title: Regularly Review and Update Consent Mechanisms
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall regularly review and update its consent mechanisms to ensure that they remain effective and compliant with changing regulatory requirements. This review shall include, but not be limited to, assessing the accessibility of the consent mechanism, verifying the age of individuals, and ensuring that the consent mechanism is usable by individuals with disabilities.

controls.control_title: Conduct Regular Risk Assessments for Children's Data
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall conduct regular risk assessments to identify potential detrimental effects of processing children's personal data. This includes assessing the likelihood and potential impact of harm to children's well-being and implementing measures to mitigate such risks.

controls.control_title: Develop and Implement a Children's Data Protection Policy
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall develop and implement a comprehensive policy for the protection of children's personal data. controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall provide clear and concise information to children and their parents about the collection, storage, and processing of their personal data. controls.control_title: Establish a Data Breach Response Plan for Children's Data
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall establish a data breach response plan to quickly respond to and contain any security incidents involving children's personal data. controls.control_title: Implement a Children's Data Protection Policy
controls.control: Develop and maintain a comprehensive policy that outlines the Data Fiduciary's commitment to protecting children's data, including procedures for obtaining parental consent, data collection, and data use.

Regularly conduct data audits to identify and eliminate any data collection or tracking activities that may be targeting children, and ensure that all data collection and use practices are compliant with applicable laws and regulations.

Implement robust age verification mechanisms to ensure that children cannot access or interact with content or services that may be targeted towards them, and to prevent the collection of personal data from children without parental consent.

controls.control_title: Train Staff on Children's Data Protection
controls.control: Provide regular training to all staff members on the Data Fiduciary's children's data protection policy, procedures, and applicable laws and regulations, to ensure that they understand their roles and responsibilities in protecting children's data.

Appoint a Data Protection Officer (DPO) who is responsible for overseeing the Data Fiduciary's children's data protection practices, ensuring compliance with applicable laws and regulations, and providing guidance to staff members on data protection issues.

controls.control_title: Maintain a Publicly Available Data Protection Statement
controls.control: Maintain a publicly available data protection statement that outlines the Data Fiduciary's children's data protection practices, including information on data collection, use, and sharing, and provide a clear process for children and parents to opt-out of data collection and targeted advertising.

requirement_title: Exemption from Applicability for Certain Data Fiduciaries
article_text:
9. (1) The Data Fiduciary shall, before processing any personal data of a child or a
person with disability who has a lawful guardian obtain verifiable consent of the parent of
such child or the lawful guardian, as the case may be, in such manner as may be prescribed.
Explanation.—For the purpose of this sub-section, the expression “consent  of the
parent” includes the consent of lawful guardian, wherever applicable.
(2) A Data Fiduciary shall not undertake such processing of personal data that is
likely to cause any detrimental effect on the well-being of a child.
(3) A Data Fiduciary shall not undertake tracking or behavioural monitoring of children
or targeted advertising directed at children.
(4) The provisions of sub-sections (1) and (3) shall not be applicable to processing of
personal data of a child by such classes of Data Fiduciaries or for such purposes, and

requirement: The Central Government shall notify Significant Data Fiduciaries based on relevant factors.
requirement_description: The Central Government must identify and notify Significant Data Fiduciaries based on specific factors, including processing of personal data of children.

controls.control: The Central Government shall establish a clear framework for notifying Significant Data Fiduciaries, including the criteria for selection, the process for notification, and the timeline for notification. This framework shall be published on the government's website and made available to the public.

The Central Government shall define and publish the relevant factors that will be used to determine which entities are Significant Data Fiduciaries. These factors may include, but are not limited to, the volume of data collected, the type of data collected, and the purpose for which the data is collected.

The Central Government shall develop a clear and transparent process for notifying Significant Data Fiduciaries, including the steps that must be taken by the entity to confirm its status as a Significant Data Fiduciary and the consequences of non-compliance.

The Central Government shall provide training and support to Significant Data Fiduciaries on the notification process and the requirements of the framework. This may include webinars, workshops, and other educational resources.

The Central Government shall establish clear consequences for Significant Data Fiduciaries that fail to comply with the notification framework, including fines, penalties, and other enforcement mechanisms.

controls.control_title: Monitor and Review the Notification Process
controls.control: The Central Government shall regularly monitor and review the notification process to ensure that it is working effectively and that Significant Data Fiduciaries are being notified in a timely manner. This may include conducting audits and reviews of the notification process.

controls.control: The Significant Data Fiduciary shall appoint a Data Protection Officer (DPO) who is responsible for overseeing the organization's data protection practices and ensuring compliance with relevant data protection regulations. The DPO shall be a senior-level employee with expertise in data protection and shall report directly to the highest level of management.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall define the DPO's responsibilities, including but not limited to: developing and implementing data protection policies and procedures, conducting data protection impact assessments, and responding to data subject requests. The DPO's responsibilities shall be documented and communicated to all employees.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall ensure that the DPO operates independently and is not influenced by business or commercial considerations. The DPO shall have the authority to investigate and report on data protection incidents and shall have access to all necessary resources and information to perform their duties.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall provide the DPO with the necessary training and resources to perform their duties, including but not limited to: data protection training, access to relevant documentation and systems, and a budget for data protection activities.

controls.control: The Significant Data Fiduciary shall review and update the DPO's role and responsibilities on a regular basis to ensure that they remain effective and relevant. This shall include reviewing the DPO's performance and providing feedback and guidance as necessary.

controls.control_title: Establish a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) Policy
controls.control: Develop and implement a policy that outlines the scope, frequency, and responsibilities for conducting DPIAs. The policy should be approved by senior management and communicated to all relevant stakeholders.

Conduct a thorough risk assessment to identify data processing activities that are likely to result in a high risk to individuals' rights and freedoms. This may include activities such as processing sensitive personal data, using new technologies, or processing large amounts of data.

Create a standardized template for conducting DPIAs that includes all necessary information and questions. The template should be reviewed and updated regularly to ensure it remains effective and relevant.

Provide training to all personnel who are responsible for conducting DPIAs, including data protection officers, IT staff, and other relevant stakeholders. The training should cover the purpose and scope of DPIAs, the requirements for conducting a DPIA, and the responsibilities of personnel involved.

Maintain a record of all DPIAs conducted, including the results, recommendations, and any subsequent actions taken. The records should be kept for a minimum of 5 years and made available to relevant stakeholders upon request.
Regularly review and update DPIAs to ensure they remain effective and relevant. This may include revising the DPIA template, updating risk assessments, or revising recommendations and actions taken.

requirement: The Significant Data Fiduciary shall undertake periodic audit.
requirement_description: The organization must conduct periodic audits to ensure compliance with this Act.

controls.control: The Significant Data Fiduciary shall conduct regular audits at least once a quarter to ensure the accuracy, completeness, and integrity of the data. The audit shall be conducted by an independent third-party auditor or an internal audit team with sufficient expertise and resources.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall document all audit findings and recommendations, including any corrective actions taken. The documentation shall be maintained for a minimum of 7 years and shall be made available to regulatory bodies upon request.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall establish an audit committee comprising of independent members with expertise in data management and security. The committee shall oversee the audit process and ensure that the audit is conducted in accordance with the established procedures.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall provide regular training to its staff on audit procedures, data management, and security best practices. The training shall be conducted at least once a year and shall be mandatory for all staff members who handle sensitive data.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall conduct risk-based audits to identify and mitigate potential risks to the data. The audit shall be conducted based on a risk assessment framework that takes into account the sensitivity of the data, the likelihood of a security breach, and the potential impact of a breach.

article_text:
12. (1) A Data Principal shall have the right to correction, completion, updating and
erasure of her personal data for the processing of which she has previously given consent,
including consent as referred to in clause (a) of section 7, in accordance with any requirement
or procedure under any law for the time being in force.
(2) A Data Fiduciary shall, upon receiving a request for correction, completion or
updating from a Data Principal,—

(b) complete the incomplete personal data; and

specified purpose or for compliance with any law for the time being in force.

Establish a process for handling data subject requests, including requests for correction, completion, updating, and erasure of personal data. Ensure that requests are processed in a timely manner and that all necessary documentation is maintained.

Implement a process for monitoring the quality of personal data, including identifying and correcting errors or inaccuracies. This includes regular data audits and reviews to ensure that data is accurate and up-to-date.

issued by the State or any of its instrumentalities;

Data Fiduciary or the Board; and
(e) to furnish only such information as is verifiably authentic, while exercising
the right to correction or erasure under the provisions of this Act or the rules made
thereunder.

article_text:
16. (1) The Central Government may, by notification, restrict the transfer of personal
data by a Data Fiduciary for processing to such country or territory outside India as may be
so notified.
(2) Nothing contained in this section shall restrict the applicability of any law for the
time being in force in India that provides for a higher degree of protection for or restriction
on transfer of personal data by a Data Fiduciary outside India in relation to any personal
data or Data Fiduciary or class thereof.
requirement: The Central Government shall restrict the transfer of personal data by a Data Fiduciary for processing to such country or territory outside India as may be notified.
requirement_description: The Central Government is required to restrict the transfer of personal data by a Data Fiduciary for processing to countries or territories outside India, as notified.

controls.control_title: Conduct a Risk Assessment for International Data Transfers
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall conduct a thorough risk assessment to identify potential risks associated with transferring personal data to countries or territories outside India. This assessment shall consider factors such as data protection laws, security measures, and potential data breaches.

controls.control_title: Obtain Prior Approval for International Data Transfers
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall obtain prior approval from the Central Government or relevant authorities before transferring personal data to countries or territories outside India. This approval shall be obtained in accordance with the notified countries or territories.

The Data Fiduciary shall implement data transfer agreements with the recipient entities outside India, which shall include provisions for data protection, security, and confidentiality. These agreements shall be reviewed and updated periodically to ensure compliance with the notified countries or territories.

controls.control_title: Monitor and Review International Data Transfers
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall regularly monitor and review international data transfers to ensure compliance with the notified countries or territories. This shall include tracking data transfers, identifying potential risks, and taking corrective actions as necessary.

controls.control_title: Maintain Records of International Data Transfers
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall maintain accurate and up-to-date records of international data transfers, including the recipient entities, data types, and transfer dates. These records shall be retained for a minimum of 5 years and made available for inspection by the Central Government or relevant authorities.

controls.control: Regularly review laws and regulations in the jurisdiction to ensure compliance with the requirement that any law providing a higher degree of protection for or restriction on transfer of personal data shall not be restricted by this section. This includes monitoring changes to laws and regulations and updating policies and procedures accordingly.

Establish a compliance framework that outlines the procedures for identifying, assessing, and addressing laws and regulations that may impact the transfer of personal data. This framework should include clear roles and responsibilities, timelines, and metrics for measuring compliance.

controls.control_title: Maintain a Record of Legal Compliance
controls.control: Maintain a record of all laws and regulations reviewed, including the date of review, the outcome of the review, and any actions taken to address any non-compliance issues. This record should be retained for a minimum of 7 years and made available to relevant authorities upon request.

Provide regular training to personnel on the requirement that any law providing a higher degree of protection for or restriction on transfer of personal data shall not be restricted by this section. This training should include an overview of the relevant laws and regulations, the procedures for identifying and addressing potential non-compliance issues, and the importance of maintaining confidentiality and data protection.

controls.control_title: Establish a Process for Identifying High-Risk Laws
controls.control: Establish a process for identifying laws and regulations that may impact the transfer of personal data, including those that provide a higher degree of protection or restriction. This process should involve regular monitoring of changes to laws and regulations, as well as input from relevant stakeholders, including legal counsel and data protection officers.

17. (1) The provisions of Chapter II, except sub-sections (1) and (5) of section 8, and
those of Chapter III and section 16 shall not apply where—
(a) the processing of personal data is necessary for enforcing any legal right or
claim;
(b) the processing of personal data by any court or tribunal or any other body
in India which is entrusted by law with the performance of any judicial or quasi-judicial
or regulatory or supervisory function, where such processing is necessary for the
performance of such function;
(c) personal data is processed in the interest of prevention, detection,
investigation or prosecution of any offence or contravention of any law for the time
being in force in India;
(d) personal data of Data Principals not within the territory of India is processed
pursuant to any contract entered into with any person outside the territory of India
by any person based in India;
(e) the processing is necessary for a scheme of compromise or arrangement or
merger or amalgamation of two or more companies or a reconstruction by way of
demerger or otherwise of a company, or transfer of undertaking of one or more company
to another company, or involving division of one or more companies, approved by a
court or tribunal or other authority competent to do so by any law for the time being
in force; and
(f) the processing is for the purpose of ascertaining the financial information
and assets and liabilities of any person who has defaulted in payment due on account
of a loan or advance taken from a financial institution, subject to such processing
being in accordance with the provisions regarding disclosure of information or data
in any other law for the time being in force.
Explanation.— For the purposes of this clause, the expressions “default” and
“financial institution” shall have the meanings respectively assigned to them in
sub-sections (12) and (14) of section 3 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016.

Classify personal data into different categories based on its sensitivity and importance. This will help in implementing appropriate security measures to protect sensitive data.

requirement: Financial institutions shall be defined according to the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016.
requirement_description: Financial institutions must be defined in accordance with the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016, specifically sub-sections (12) and (14) of section 3.

controls.control: Establish a clear process to determine whether an entity is a financial institution as per the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016. This includes identifying the types of entities that fall under the definition of a financial institution and ensuring that all relevant entities are classified correctly.

Ensure that all records related to financial institutions, including their classification and status, are accurate, complete, and up-to-date. This includes maintaining a centralized database or repository of financial institution information.

Provide regular training to staff on the definition of financial institutions under the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016, and their classification. This includes ensuring that staff understand the importance of accurate classification and the consequences of incorrect classification.

Establish a regular review process to ensure that the classification of financial institutions is accurate and up-to-date. This includes reviewing the classification of entities at least annually and updating the classification as necessary.

Ensure that all stakeholders, including customers, regulators, and other interested parties, are aware of the definition of financial institutions under the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016, and the classification of entities. This includes providing clear and concise information on the classification process and the consequences of incorrect classification.

requirement: The provisions of this Act shall not apply to processing of personal data by State instrumentality in certain circumstances.
requirement_description: The provisions of this Act do not apply to the processing of personal data by State instrumentality in situations related to sovereignty, security, public order, or foreign relations.

controls.control: Establish clear guidelines and procedures for determining when the provisions of this Act do not apply to the processing of personal data by State instrumentality. This includes identifying specific circumstances, such as national security or law enforcement activities, where exemptions may apply.

Implement a system to classify and label personal data that is exempt from the provisions of this Act due to State instrumentality processing. This will help ensure that exempt data is handled and protected in accordance with applicable laws and regulations.

Maintain accurate and up-to-date records of exemptions granted to State instrumentality for processing personal data. Include a clear rationale for each exemption, including the specific circumstances and applicable laws or regulations that justify the exemption.

Establish procedures to ensure transparency and accountability when processing personal data by State instrumentality, even if exempt from the provisions of this Act. This includes providing clear information to individuals about the processing of their data and ensuring that data protection principles are respected.

Regularly conduct risk assessments to identify potential risks and vulnerabilities associated with the processing of personal data by State instrumentality, even if exempt from the provisions of this Act. This will help ensure that necessary controls are in place to mitigate these risks and protect personal data.

requirement: The provisions of this Act shall not apply to processing of personal data outside India.
requirement_description: The provisions of this Act do not apply to the processing of personal data outside India.

controls.control: Identify and document all locations where personal data is processed outside India. This includes servers, data centers, and any other locations where personal data is stored, transmitted, or processed.

Establish and maintain data transfer agreements with all third-party vendors and service providers that process personal data outside India. These agreements must include provisions for data protection, security, and compliance with Indian data protection laws.

Notify the relevant authorities and stakeholders within the organization about the processing of personal data outside India. This includes providing information about the locations where data is processed, the types of data being processed, and the measures in place to protect the data.

controls.control_title: Data Processing Outside India Record Keeping
controls.control: Maintain records of all personal data processed outside India, including information about the data, the locations where it was processed, and the measures in place to protect the data. These records must be kept for a minimum of 5 years.

Conduct a data protection impact assessment (DPIA) for all personal data processing activities that take place outside India. The DPIA must identify and mitigate any risks associated with the processing of personal data outside India.

requirement: A bank may process personal data of a loan defaulter for financial assessment.
requirement_description: A bank has the right to process personal data of a loan defaulter to assess their financial situation, assets, and liabilities.

controls.control: Only collect and process the minimum amount of personal data necessary for financial assessment. This includes data such as loan history, credit score, and income verification.
Verify the accuracy of personal data collected from loan defaulter, including data sources and validation procedures to ensure data is up-to-date and reliable.
Establish a data retention policy to ensure personal data is stored for a limited period, and deleted or anonymized after the financial assessment is completed.
Implement access controls to restrict access to personal data to authorized personnel only, and ensure that access is granted based on job function and need-to-know principle.
Encrypt personal data in transit and at rest to protect against unauthorized access and data breaches.
Notify the loan defaulter of the collection and processing of their personal data, and provide information on how to access and correct their data.
Establish procedures to handle data subject requests for access, correction, and deletion of their personal data, in accordance with applicable data protection laws.

requirement: Personal data shall not be used to take any decision specific to a Data Principal for research, archiving, or statistical purposes.
requirement_description: Personal data can be processed for research, archiving, or statistical purposes, but it cannot be used to make decisions that affect the data principal.

controls.control: Anonymize personal data before using it for research, archiving, or statistical purposes to prevent identification of Data Principals. This can be achieved through techniques such as data masking, encryption, or pseudonymization.

Only collect and process the minimum amount of personal data necessary for research, archiving, or statistical purposes. Avoid collecting sensitive or unnecessary data that could be used to identify Data Principals.
Implement role-based access controls to restrict access to personal data to authorized personnel only. Ensure that access is granted based on job function and need-to-know principles.

Establish a data retention and disposal policy that outlines the duration for which personal data will be stored and the procedures for its disposal. Ensure that personal data is deleted or anonymized after the retention period has expired.

Develop and implement a data use policy that outlines the purposes for which personal data can be used, including research, archiving, and statistical purposes. Ensure that the policy is communicated to all personnel and Data Principals.

Establish procedures for Data Principals to exercise their rights, including the right to object to the use of their personal data for research, archiving, or statistical purposes. Ensure that these procedures are communicated to Data Principals and made easily accessible.

controls.control: Maintain a list of Data Fiduciaries that are exempt from the provisions of section 5, sub-sections (3) and (7) of section 8, and sections 10 and 11. The list should be regularly reviewed and updated to ensure accuracy and compliance with the exemption policy.

controls.control_title: Monitor and Report on Exemption Compliance

Regularly review and update the exemption policy to ensure it remains effective and compliant with changing regulations. This will help ensure that the exemption policy continues to meet the needs of the organization and its stakeholders.

controls.control: Data Fiduciaries must establish a clear policy outlining the conditions under which they will apply for a temporary exemption from specific provisions of the Act. This policy should be communicated to all stakeholders, including employees, customers, and partners.

Data Fiduciaries must designate an officer responsible for handling exemption requests. This officer should be knowledgeable about the Act and the exemption process, and should be able to provide guidance to employees and stakeholders.

Data Fiduciaries must maintain accurate and up-to-date records of all exemption requests, including the date of submission, the specific provisions of the Act being exempted, and the outcome of the request.

Data Fiduciaries must ensure that exemption requests are transparent and publicly available. This includes publishing information about the exemption request on the Data Fiduciary's website, and providing stakeholders with regular updates on the status of the request.

controls.control_title: Conduct Regular Reviews of Exemption Requests
controls.control: Data Fiduciaries must conduct regular reviews of exemption requests to ensure that they are being used appropriately and in accordance with the Act. This includes reviewing the effectiveness of the exemption policy and making any necessary adjustments.

Data Fiduciaries must provide regular training to employees on the exemption process and the requirements of the Act. This includes training on how to submit exemption requests, and how to ensure that exemption requests are handled in accordance with the Act.

requirement_title: Establishment of the Data Protection Board of India
article_text:
CHAPTER V
D
ATA PROTECTION BOARD OF INDIA
18. (1) With effect from such date as the Central Government may, by notification,
appoint, there shall be established, for the purposes of this Act, a Board to be called the
Data Protection Board of India.
(2) The Board shall be a body corporate by the name aforesaid, having perpetual
succession and a common seal, with power, subject to the provisions of this Act, to acquire,
hold and dispose of property, both movable and immovable, and to contract and shall, by
the said name, sue or be sued.
(3) The headquarters of the Board shall be at such place as the Central Government
may notify.
19. (1) The Board shall consist of a Chairperson and such number of other Members
as the Central Government may notify.
(2) The Chairperson and other Members shall be appointed by the Central Government
in such manner as may be prescribed.
(3) The Chairperson and other Members shall be a person of ability, integrity and
standing who possesses special knowledge or practical experience in the fields of data
governance, administration or implementation of laws related to social or consumer
protection, dispute resolution, information and communication technology, digital economy,
law, regulation or techno-regulation, or in any other field which in the opinion of the Central
Government may be useful to the Board, and at least one among them shall be an expert in
the field of law.
20. ( 1) The salary, allowances and other terms and conditions of service of the
Chairperson and other Members shall be such as may be prescribed, and shall not be varied
to their disadvantage after their appointment.
(2) The Chairperson and other Members shall hold office for a term of two years and
shall be eligible for re-appointment.

requirement: The Data Protection Board of India shall be established.
requirement_description: The Central Government must establish the Data Protection Board of India by a notification.

controls.control_title: Establish a Data Protection Board of India
controls.control: Establish a dedicated Data Protection Board of India with a clear mandate to oversee and enforce data protection laws and regulations. The Board should comprise of experts in data protection, law, and technology.

controls.control_title: Define the Board's Mandate and Responsibilities
controls.control: Clearly define the Data Protection Board of India's mandate, responsibilities, and powers to ensure effective oversight and enforcement of data protection laws and regulations. This should include the authority to investigate data breaches, impose penalties, and provide guidance to organizations.

controls.control_title: Establish a Secretariat for the Data Protection Board
controls.control: Establish a secretariat to support the Data Protection Board of India in its functions, including providing administrative support, coordinating with stakeholders, and maintaining records of the Board's activities and decisions.

controls.control_title: Develop a Budget and Resource Plan
controls.control: Develop a budget and resource plan to ensure the Data Protection Board of India has sufficient resources to carry out its functions effectively. This should include funding for personnel, infrastructure, and operational costs.

Establish a public awareness program to educate the public about the Data Protection Board of India and its functions, as well as the importance of data protection and privacy. This can include public outreach campaigns, educational materials, and community engagement initiatives.

controls.control: The Board shall designate a specific address as its headquarters and ensure that it is notified to the relevant authorities. This address shall be used for all official correspondence and communication.

controls.control_title: Ensure Compliance with Notified Headquarters Address

Ensure that the Chairperson or Member is provided with written notice of the intention to remove them, including the reasons for the removal and the opportunity to be heard. The notice should be delivered in a timely manner, allowing the Chairperson or Member sufficient time to prepare their response.

Arrange for a fair and impartial hearing to be conducted, where the Chairperson or Member can present their case and respond to any allegations made against them. The hearing should be chaired by an independent person and attended by relevant stakeholders.

Maintain a record of all removal decisions, including the reasons for the removal, the outcome of any hearing, and any subsequent actions taken. This will help to ensure transparency and accountability in the removal process.
Ensure that the Chairperson or Member can only be removed for just cause, such as misconduct, incompetence, or failure to perform their duties. This will help to prevent arbitrary or unfair removals.

article_text:
22. (1) The Chairperson or any other Member may give notice in writing to the Central
Government of resigning from her office, and such resignation shall be effective from the
date on which the Central Government permits her to relinquish office, or upon expiry of a
period of three months from the date of receipt of such notice, or upon a duly appointed
successor entering upon her office, or upon the expiry of the term of her office, whichever
is earliest.
(2) A vacancy caused by the resignation or removal or death of the Chairperson or
any other Member, or otherwise, shall be filled by fresh appointment in accordance with the
provisions of this Act.
(3) The Chairperson and any other Member shall not, for a period of one year from the
date on which they cease to hold such office, except with the previous approval of the
Central Government, accept any employment, and shall also disclose to the Central
Government any subsequent acceptance of employment with any Data Fiduciary against
whom proceedings were initiated by or before such Chairperson or other Member.
requirement: A resignation notice shall be effective within three months from the date of receipt or upon a duly appointed successor entering office.
requirement_description: The resignation notice period is three months, or upon a new appointment, whichever comes first.

controls.control: Establish a clear process for receiving resignation notices, including the method of delivery (e.g., email, mail, in-person) and the responsible personnel for acknowledging receipt. This process should ensure that all resignation notices are recorded and timestamped.

controls.control_title: Set Clear Effective Date for Resignation Notice
controls.control: Implement a system to automatically calculate the effective date of a resignation notice, which should be within three months from the date of receipt or upon a duly appointed successor entering office. This system should take into account any applicable leave or notice periods.

controls.control_title: Communicate Resignation Notice Policy to Employees
controls.control: Develop and disseminate a clear policy on resignation notices to all employees, including the requirements for providing notice, the effective date of resignation, and the process for submitting a resignation notice. This policy should be easily accessible and understood by all employees.

Establish a system to monitor and track resignation notices, including the date of receipt, effective date, and any subsequent actions taken. This system should provide a clear audit trail and enable management to identify trends and patterns in employee turnover.

controls.control_title: Ensure Duly Appointed Successor is Identified
controls.control: Develop a process to identify and appoint a duly qualified successor in the event of an employee's resignation. This process should ensure that the successor is aware of their responsibilities and is prepared to assume their role upon the effective date of the resignation notice.

as may be prescribed.

when acting or purporting to act in pursuance of provisions of this Act, to be public

controls.control: Establish a process to verify the eligibility of Board members before each meeting to ensure that all members are qualified and meet the required criteria.
Ensure that accurate and detailed meeting minutes are maintained for each Board meeting, including a record of all decisions made and actions taken.

controls.control_title: Establish a Process for Filling Vacancies
controls.control: Develop a clear process for filling Board vacancies in a timely manner, including procedures for selecting interim members and holding special elections.
Provide regular training and education to Board members on their roles and responsibilities, as well as any relevant laws and regulations.
Regularly review and update the Board's bylaws to ensure they are current and compliant with relevant laws and regulations.
Verify that the required quorum of Board members is present at each meeting to ensure that valid decisions can be made.

requirement: The Board shall appoint officers and employees with the Central Government's approval.

controls.control: The Board shall establish a committee responsible for recommending officers and employees for appointment. This committee shall comprise of senior members of the Board and shall be responsible for ensuring that all appointments are made in accordance with the Central Government's guidelines and regulations.

controls.control_title: Obtain Central Government's Approval for Appointments
controls.control: The Board shall obtain the Central Government's approval for all appointments of officers and employees. This approval shall be obtained prior to making any appointments and shall be documented in the Board's records.

The Board shall develop a policy for the appointment of officers and employees. This policy shall outline the procedures for appointment, the qualifications and experience required for each position, and the criteria for selection.

The Board shall maintain a record of all appointments made, including the names of the officers and employees appointed, their positions, and the dates of appointment. This record shall be kept up-to-date and shall be made available for inspection by the Central Government upon request.

The Board shall conduct background checks on all appointees prior to their appointment. This shall include verification of their qualifications, experience, and character, as well as any other relevant information.

Implement a process to verify the public servant status of all individuals, including the Chairperson, Members, officers, and employees, to ensure compliance with the policy.

controls.control_title: Train Staff on Public Servant Responsibilities
controls.control: Provide regular training to staff on their responsibilities as public servants, including the importance of maintaining confidentiality, avoiding conflicts of interest, and adhering to organizational policies and procedures.

Keep accurate and up-to-date records of public servant status, including documentation of training, certifications, and any changes to public servant status. These records should be easily accessible and maintained in accordance with organizational policies and procedures.

requirement: The Chairperson shall exercise general superintendence and give direction in respect of all administrative matters of the Board.
requirement_description: The Chairperson has the authority to oversee and direct all administrative matters of the Board.

controls.control: The Chairperson shall clearly define their roles and responsibilities in relation to the Board's administrative matters, including decision-making authority and areas of oversight. This shall be documented in a Board charter or similar governance document.

The Chairperson shall schedule regular meetings with the Board to discuss administrative matters, provide direction, and ensure that the Board is informed and engaged. This shall include regular updates on key issues and decisions.
The Chairperson shall ensure that all decisions and actions related to administrative matters are documented and recorded, including minutes of meetings and written records of key decisions.

The Chairperson shall oversee the administration of the Board's functions, including the management of resources, personnel, and operations. This shall include regular reviews and assessments of administrative processes and procedures.

The Chairperson shall ensure that the Board receives regular training and development opportunities to enhance their knowledge and skills in relation to administrative matters, including governance best practices and regulatory requirements.

controls.control_title: Review and Revision of Governance Documents
controls.control: The Chairperson shall regularly review and revise the Board's governance documents, including the Board charter and other policies and procedures, to ensure they remain relevant and effective in supporting the Board's administrative functions.

requirement_description: The Chairperson can delegate Board functions and proceedings to individual Members or groups of Members and allocate tasks among them.

controls.control: Establish a clear policy that outlines the Chairperson's authority to delegate tasks and allocate proceedings among Board Members. This policy should be documented and communicated to all Members.

Maintain a log of all tasks and proceedings delegated by the Chairperson to individual Members or groups of Members. This log should be regularly reviewed and updated to ensure accountability and transparency.

Provide regular training and awareness sessions for Board Members on their roles and responsibilities, including the Chairperson's delegation authority and the allocation of proceedings. This will ensure that all Members understand their duties and can perform them effectively.

Develop a checklist for the Chairperson to use when delegating tasks and allocating proceedings. This checklist should ensure that all necessary steps are taken and that the delegation is properly documented.

Establish a review and approval process for all delegated tasks and allocated proceedings. This process should ensure that the Chairperson's delegation is properly authorized and that all Members are aware of their responsibilities.

requirement: The Board shall be identified.
requirement_description: The Board members must be clearly identified and recognized.

controls.control: Establish a formal Board Charter that outlines the Board's roles, responsibilities, and expectations. The Charter should be approved by the Board and reviewed annually or as needed.
Maintain a list of all Board members, including their names, titles, and contact information. Ensure that all Board members are aware of their roles and responsibilities.

Maintain accurate and complete records of all Board meetings, including meeting dates, times, locations, and outcomes. Ensure that meeting minutes are approved by the Board and retained for a minimum of 7 years.

controls.control: Develop a Board Charter that outlines the roles, responsibilities, and expectations of the Board. The charter should be approved by the Board and reviewed annually.
Establish a procedure for scheduling, conducting, and documenting Board meetings. This should include a clear agenda, minutes, and action items.
Appoint a Board Secretary to be responsible for maintaining Board records, preparing meeting materials, and ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements.
Offer regular training and education to Board members on their roles, responsibilities, and compliance requirements. This can be done through workshops, webinars, or other training sessions.

controls.control_title: Establish a Conflict of Interest Policy
controls.control: Develop a Conflict of Interest Policy that outlines the procedures for disclosing and managing conflicts of interest. This policy should be approved by the Board and communicated to all stakeholders.

controls.control_title: Maintain a Personal Data Breach Incident Log
controls.control: The organization shall maintain a personal data breach incident log to track and record all breaches, including the date and time of the breach, the type of breach, and the remediation actions taken.

Appoint a designated officer responsible for receiving and investigating breach notifications. This officer should be knowledgeable about the Consent Manager registration conditions and the procedures for notifying the Board.

Develop and implement a system for receiving and tracking breach notifications. This system should include a process for documenting and investigating breaches, as well as a mechanism for notifying the Board in a timely manner.

Regularly conduct audits to ensure that the Consent Manager registration conditions are being met. These audits should include a review of the organization's policies and procedures, as well as a review of the organization's compliance with relevant laws and regulations.

controls.control_title: Provide Training on Breach Notification Procedures
controls.control: Provide training to employees on the procedures for notifying the Board in the event of a breach of Consent Manager registration conditions. This training should include information on the organization's policies and procedures, as well as the roles and responsibilities of employees in the event of a breach.

Develop and implement an incident response plan that outlines the procedures for responding to a breach of Consent Manager registration conditions. The plan should include clear guidelines on containment, eradication, recovery, and post-incident activities.

Establish a compliance committee that is responsible for overseeing the organization's compliance with the Consent Manager registration conditions. The committee should include representatives from various departments and should meet regularly to discuss compliance issues and develop strategies for improving compliance.

namely:—

article_text:

function as a digital office, with the receipt of complaints and the allocation, hearing and
pronouncement of decisions in respect of the same being digital by design, and adopt such
techno-legal measures as may be prescribed.
(2) The Board may, on receipt of an intimation or complaint or reference or directions
as referred to in sub-section (1) of section 27, take action in accordance with the provisions
of this Act and the rules made thereunder.

requirement: The Board shall function as an independent body and as a digital office.

controls.control: Ensure that all Board members are appointed based on their expertise and skills, and not based on any personal relationships or affiliations with the organization. The Board should have a diverse composition to ensure that it can make informed decisions.

Establish a digital office infrastructure that enables the Board to function effectively, including secure and reliable communication tools, document management systems, and data storage solutions.
Provide regular training and development opportunities for Board members to enhance their skills and knowledge, particularly in areas related to digital governance and technology.
Implement robust security measures to protect the digital office infrastructure from cyber threats, including regular software updates, firewalls, and antivirus software.
Establish a feedback mechanism to collect suggestions and ideas from Board members on how to improve the digital office infrastructure and its operations.
Maintain accurate and up-to-date documentation of the digital office infrastructure, including user manuals, technical specifications, and maintenance records.

controls.control: The Board shall provide adequate notice to all parties involved in the inquiry, including the opportunity to be heard and to present evidence. This notice shall be in writing and shall specify the date, time, and location of the inquiry, as well as the issues to be addressed.

The Board shall ensure that the hearing process is fair and impartial, with all parties having an equal opportunity to present their case. This may involve the use of a neutral chairperson or moderator to facilitate the discussion and ensure that all parties are heard.

The Board shall maintain the confidentiality of the inquiry, including all evidence and testimony presented. This may involve the use of secure storage facilities and restricted access to sensitive information.

The Board shall document the inquiry process, including all evidence presented, testimony taken, and decisions made. This documentation shall be maintained in a secure and accessible location, and shall be available for review by relevant parties.

article_text:
CHAPTER VII
A
PPEAL AND ALTERNATE DISPUTE RESOLUTION
29. (1) Any person aggrieved by an order or direction made by the Board under this
Act may prefer an appeal before the Appellate Tribunal.
(2) Every appeal under sub-section (1) shall be filed within a period of sixty days from
the date of receipt of the order or direction appealed against and it shall be in such form and
manner and shall be accompanied by such fee as may be prescribed.
(3) The Appellate Tribunal may entertain an appeal after the expiry of the period
specified in sub-section (2), if it is satisfied that there was sufficient cause for not preferring
the appeal within that period.
(4) On receipt of an appeal under sub-section ( 1), the Appellate Tribunal may, after
giving the parties to the appeal, an opportunity of being heard, pass such orders thereon as
it thinks fit, confirming, modifying or setting aside the order appealed against.

requirement: The Appellate Tribunal shall pass orders on appeals, confirming, modifying, or setting aside the original order.
requirement_description: The Appellate Tribunal has the authority to confirm, modify, or set aside the original order, as it deems fit.

controls.control: The Appellate Tribunal shall have a designated review process to verify that orders are accurate, complete, and comply with the applicable laws and regulations. This process shall include a thorough review of the original order, the appeal, and any supporting documentation.
All orders passed by the Appellate Tribunal shall be approved and authenticated by a designated officer or committee. This shall ensure that orders are legitimate and binding on all parties involved.

The Appellate Tribunal shall maintain accurate and complete records of all orders, including the original order, the appeal, and any supporting documentation. These records shall be securely stored and made available for inspection upon request.

The Appellate Tribunal shall notify all parties involved in the appeal of the order, including the original order, the appeal, and any supporting documentation. This shall be done in a timely and transparent manner, using secure communication channels.

The Appellate Tribunal shall have a clear process for modifying or cancelling orders, including the procedures for requesting modifications or cancellations, and the criteria for approving or rejecting such requests.

The Appellate Tribunal shall have a system in place to track and monitor the status of orders, including the date and time of issuance, the parties involved, and any subsequent modifications or cancellations.

controls.control: Develop a clear and comprehensive framework to classify breaches as significant or non-significant. This framework should be based on factors such as the severity of the breach, the potential impact on stakeholders, and the likelihood of recurrence.

Establish clear and specific penalties for significant breaches, including financial penalties, disciplinary actions, and other consequences. These penalties should be communicated to all stakeholders, including employees, customers, and partners.

Create a comprehensive breach response plan that outlines the procedures for responding to significant breaches, including notification requirements, containment and mitigation strategies, and post-breach review and improvement processes.

Regularly review and update the penalties for significant breaches to ensure they remain effective and relevant. This may involve revising the breach classification framework, updating the penalties themselves, or modifying the procedures for applying the penalties.

controls.control_title: Define Clear Acceptance Criteria for Voluntary Undertakings
controls.control: Establish a clear set of criteria for accepting voluntary undertakings for significant breaches. This should include specific requirements for the undertaking, such as the actions to be taken, timelines for completion, and consequences for non-compliance. The criteria should be documented and communicated to all relevant stakeholders.

controls.control_title: Establish a Review Process for Voluntary Undertakings
controls.control: Develop a review process to assess the adequacy of voluntary undertakings for significant breaches. This should include regular reviews of the undertaking, monitoring of progress, and evaluation of the effectiveness of the actions taken. The review process should be documented and communicated to all relevant stakeholders.

Maintain a record of all voluntary undertakings accepted for significant breaches. The record should include the details of the undertaking, the criteria used to accept it, and the outcome of any reviews or evaluations. The record should be easily accessible and retrievable for auditing and compliance purposes.

Assign accountability for the acceptance and implementation of voluntary undertakings for significant breaches. This should include designating a specific individual or team to oversee the process and ensure that the undertaking is implemented effectively. The individual or team should be held accountable for any failures or non-compliance.

controls.control_title: Communicate Voluntary Undertakings to Relevant Stakeholders

controls.control: Develop and implement a comprehensive breach response policy that outlines procedures for identifying, containing, and mitigating the effects of significant breaches. The policy should include clear roles and responsibilities, communication protocols, and incident management procedures.

Appoint a dedicated breach response team with clear roles and responsibilities to handle significant breaches. The team should include representatives from relevant departments, such as IT, security, and compliance.

Develop and implement a breach notification process that includes procedures for notifying affected parties, regulatory bodies, and other stakeholders in the event of a significant breach. The process should be clearly documented and communicated to all relevant personnel.

Perform regular risk assessments to identify potential vulnerabilities and areas of high risk related to significant breaches. These assessments should be conducted at least annually and after any significant changes to the organization's systems or processes.

Maintain a log of all significant breaches, including the date, time, and details of the breach, as well as the actions taken to respond to and mitigate the breach. This log should be used to track trends and identify areas for improvement.

controls.control: The Board shall establish clear and transparent criteria for determining monetary penalties, including the factors to be considered and the thresholds for each level of penalty. This criteria shall be documented and communicated to all relevant stakeholders.

The Board shall ensure that monetary penalties are determined consistently, taking into account the specific circumstances of each case and the relevant criteria established. This shall be achieved through regular review and audit of penalty determinations.

controls.control_title: Ensure Compliance with Relevant Laws and Regulations
controls.control: The Board shall ensure that monetary penalties are determined in compliance with all relevant laws and regulations, including any applicable statutes, regulations, and industry standards.
